column2: What do you say in these situations? Complete the sentences and put the verb in the correct form.
column3:
Joe goes out. Five minutes later, the phone rings and the caller says, 'Can I speak to Joe?'
You say:
I'm afraid {{c1::he's just gone|he has just gone|he just went}} (he / just / go) out.

column2: What do you say in these situations? Complete the sentences and put the verb in the correct form.
column3:
Your friend is going to do a course. You don't know whether the course has started or not.
You ask:
What about your course? {{c1::Has it started yet|Did it start yet}} (it / start / yet)?

column2: What do you say in these situations? Complete the sentences and put the verb in the correct form.
column3:
You plan to eat at a restaurant tonight. You phoned to reserve a table. Later your friend says, 'Shall I phone to reserve a table?'
You say:
No, it's OK. {{c1::I've already done|I have already done|I already did}} (I / already / do) it.

column2: What do you say in these situations? Complete the sentences and put the verb in the correct form.
column3:
You know that your friend was thinking about where to go on holiday. Maybe he has made a decision.
You ask:
Where are you going on holiday? {{c1::Have you decided yet|Did you decide yet}} (you / decide / yet)?

column2: What do you say in these situations? Complete the sentences and put the verb in the correct form.
column3:
You are eating in a restaurant. The waiter thinks you have finished and starts to take your plate away.
You say:
Wait a minute! I {{c1::haven't finished yet|have not finished yet|didn't finish yet}} (not / finish / yet).

column2: What do you say in these situations? Complete the sentences and put the verb in the correct form.
column3:
Linda went shopping, but a few minutes ago she returned. Somebody asks, 'Is Linda still out shopping?'
You say:
No, {{c1::she's just come|she has just come|she just came}} (she / just / come) back.
